Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Advances in the Theory and Practice of Low-Rank Matrix Recovery and Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns one of the fundamental challenges facing
contemporary science and engineering today, namely, the efficient
processing and analysis of massive amounts of high-dimensional data,
such as images, videos, web pages, and bioinformatics data. In short,
data now routinely lie in thousands or even billions of dimensions. On
the one hand, massive data collection is motivated by 1) scientific
discovery and 2) the need for better engineering systems. On the other
hand, the difficult task now is to conduct meaningful inference in
such high dimensions, and draw correct conclusions from limited
amounts of sample data and with limited computational
resources. Fortunately, scientific or engineering data often have very
low intrinsic complexity and dimensionality. This project addresses
the opportunities offered by this common situation, establishes
conditions under which reliable inference is actually possible, and
develops computational tools for extracting key information from huge
data sets.

This interdisciplinary project is expected to have three outcomes: 1)
the development of innovative mathematics needed to study the recovery
of data matrices from partial and corrupted information 2) the
development of effective algorithms for recovering low-rank matrices
and performing accurate dimensionality reduction with corrupted data
and 3) the development of novel applications in which these techniques
are expected to considerably advance the state-of-the-art. With these
new tools, scientists and engineers will be able to efficiently
extract correct information from data, which was previously
inaccessible or intractable by conventional techniques. This will
enable the development of far better computer vision systems for face
recognition, better compression schemes of video sequences, a better
understanding of gene expression data, or better search engines for
web documents and images.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A first outcome of this proposal concerns the famous phase retrieval problem, which traverses several areas of science including X-ray crystallography, diffraction imaging, astronomical imaging and many others. In such imaging applications, we have to deal with the fact that we can only observe the amplitude of the light wave and not its phase; this is because light detectors are unable to track the oscillations of the electrical field at very high frequencies. Since the phase of the light wave carries much information that is systematically lost in the measurement process, this problem has challenged mathematicians and physicists alike for a hundred years. Indeed, if we could observe the phase, the input-output relation would be linear and we could make an image by solving a system of linear equations; in a diffraction experiment, we would only need to invert the Fourier transform.

We introduced a novel framework for addressing the phase retrieval problem. Our approach combines multiple structured illuminations together with novel algorithmic ideas. First, we showed how we could use convex programming in a technique we termed `PhaseLift' to find solution algorithms. Second, inspired by lessons from the theory and practice of compressed sensing, we proposed modulating the image of interest before collecting the intensity of its diffraction pattern, each modulation thereby producing a sort of coded diffraction pattern. Mathematically, we established that if these modulations are sufficiently randomized, then PhaseLift provably recovers the missing phase and, consequently, the image of interest without any error. This is of consequence because phase retrieval asks for the solution to quadratic equations, a problem which, in general, is known to be computationally extremely difficult (it is NP-hard). In this context, our work implies that for most systems quadratic equations, the solution to a simple convex program happens to be exact. Not close. Exact. In other words, there is a regime in which what is supposedly combinatorially hard is, in fact, not. The theory extends to quadratic equations corrupted with noise and we proved that when the data is corrupted by a small amount of noise, the recovery is provably accurate as well.

In order to speed up the reconstruction time, we further introduced a class of novel non-convex algorithms, dubbed Wirtinger flows. For a model of quadratic equations, we showed that we can provably solve the phase retrieval problem from noiseless data from about the time it takes to solve a least-squares problems of the same size, had we observed the phase of the electric field. Further, we developed new algorithms adapted to problems with noisy data and statistical theory showing that these fast algorithms are nearly optimal in the sense that they achieve the best distortion one could ever obtain by any algorithm — tractable or not. The empirical performance are such that they can play a major role on phase retrieval problems currently at the center of significant research efforts collectively known under the name of coherent diffraction imaging; among other things, these efforts are aimed at determining the 3D structure of large protein complexes. Also our ability to visualize large 3D protein complexes, will have a positive impact on drug design. 

A second outcome concerns the reproducibility of scientifc research. In many fields of science, we observe a response variable (e.g. whether or not an individual is carrying a disease) together with a large number of potential explanatory variables (e.g. variations in a single nucleotide at hundreds of thousands oflocations on the genome), and would like to be able to discover which variables are truly associated with the response. At the same time, we need to know that the false discovery rate -- the expected fraction of false discoveries among all discoveries -- is not too high, in order to assure the scientist that most of the discoveries are indeed true and replicable. Short of guarantees of this kind, the error rate among published claims may be very high, leading even to current speculation that "most published research findings are false" [Ioannidis, 2005], compare the enormous attention the replicability crisis is receiving both in the scientific community and media outlets. We introduced the knockoff filter, a novel variable selection procedure controlling the FDR in a variety of statistical models. This methodology provides valid statistical tools that achieve exact FDR control in finite sample settings no matter the value of the unknown parameters being tested (the regression parameters), so that the scientist can beassured that most discoveries hold true and are reproducible.

This reproducibility failure discussed bears a substantial cost. Our tools should be of interest to society to the extent that we are concerned by the cost, the waste of time and resources, associated with following false leads and promises.
